conclusion: Use the law of refraction and the condition for total internal reflection.
The law of refraction states the ratio of the sine of the angle of incidence to the sine of the angle of refraction equals the ratio of the indices of refraction.
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence is greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle is given by θc = sin⁻¹(n2/n1).
Light travels from the outer medium (air) to the inner core of the optical fiber, so n1 < n2.
The angle of incidence in the outer medium is α = 45°, and the angle of refraction in the inner core is θ.
For total internal reflection, the angle of incidence in the inner core must be greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle θc is the angle of incidence in the inner core for which the angle of refraction is 90°.
The critical angle θc is also given by θc = sin⁻¹(n_core/n_outer).
Since light is just about to undergo total internal reflection, the angle of incidence in the inner core is θc, and the angle of refraction is 90°.
Using Snell's law: n_outer sin α = n_core sin θ
For total internal reflection, θ = 90° - θc, and sin θ = cos θc.
n_outer sin α = n_core cos θc
Since θc = sin⁻¹(n_core/n_outer), cos θc = √(1 - (n_core/n_outer)²).
Substitute into the equation: n_outer sin α = n_core √(1 - (n_core/n_outer)²)
Solving for θ: sin θ = (n_outer sin α)/(n_core) √(1 - (n_core/n_outer)²)

The angle of incidence in the inner core is 90° - θ, and for total internal reflection, this angle must be the critical angle.
